reviewText: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance*This one was a pretty good, mostly engaging story.  It had some great acting by Jimmy Stewart, John Wayne, and Lee Marvin.  Photography is great (even if it is black and white), and the DVD's video/sound quality do it good justice.  Unfortunately, it has no special features to speak of.  It is in widescreen (enhanced for 16:9 TVs), English subtitles, and your choice of Dolby Digital, 5.0 surround, or mono.Shane*Although it can be seen as dull or dumb, it is really a good classic with very excellent photography, a simple story, and phenomenal characters.  The DVD has good video quality in general; it's not very sharp, but the colors are brilliant.  The sound is not bad.  It has only a commentary as a special feature.  It's only in fullscreen.  It has English subtitles, and your choice of Dolby Digital, 2.0 surround, or French mono.Both films are classy and good.  Some modern audiences may find them outdated, but most western fans should enjoy them (and it's not a bad price either).
summary: A Gun is Only as Good or as Bad as the Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

reviewText: Two of my favorite westerns of all time.  Entertaining throughout, and star acting.  Lee marvin, one of the greatest actors in my opinion of all time was brilliant in, "The man Who Shot Liberty Valance".  He plays a villian like none other.  Alan Ladd's character in, "Shane", was so mild mannered and helpful to those in need. He was also brave, tough, and would not back down from a fight if you tried to bully him or those he was helping.  The story lines were great. These movies are classics and will never be replaced by today's modern westerns.  The great western movies and western movie actor's are gone forever.

reviewText: Two great  --and that's not an exaggeration-- actors and a fine script, with excellent photography, Liberty Valance is more evidence that the Western, often maligned, provided some of the better Hollywood movies of that generation. .  (Of course there were some bad westerns, but look at today's output, with the formulaic car chase and buddy-with-the-snappy=jokes crud.)  As for Shane, well, that's long been considered a classic, and one of the two or three best westerns ever.  Shane alone would rate five stars; Liberty four, but there's no half-step here.  An excellent afternoon of film viewing.
summary: Two of the best from the past

reviewText: There may not be two better Westerns ever made. Both movies explore the settling of the West and the battle between the ranchers (bad guys) and the settlers (good guys).Shane's beautiful photography is spellbinding. Alan Ladd and Van Heflin turn in great performances and Jean Arthur is stunning. The supporting cast is unbelievable.Liberty Valance, shot in B/W, also has stunning photography. John Wayne, James Stewart and Lee Marvin are in top form. Many, many great moments in this movie ("No, YOU pick it up Valance", "Print the legend").This is great double feature (just like the old days) at a very affordable price!

reviewText: Two westerns based on literary classics, Dorothy Johnson's short story "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" and  Jack Schaeffer's novel "Shane." Both stories date from the 1940s and are attempts to raise the western a notch or two above the shoot-em-up conventions of pulp fiction. The originals, I will argue, are better than the films, and given the strength of the films, that's giving 5 stars to Johnson and Schaeffer.Johnson's story is an ironic portrayal of Old West heroism. An all around top cowboy, who compares well with Owen Wister's Virginian, saves the life of a lawyer newly arrived from the East, who wants to practice law in a land where law is chiefly administered at the point of a gun. In attempting to bring the outlaw Liberty Valance to justice, he is drawn into a shoot-out that the experienced gunfighter is sure to win. Surprisingly, the reverse happens, and years later the young lawyer rises to prominence as a politician, while the cowboy is a has-been, having outlived his time. He also loses his girl to the lawyer.In Schaeffer's novel, homesteaders are in conflict for the right to their land with a cattleman trying to drive them off. A gunfighter comes to their rescue, and Schaeffer portrays the unlikely coming together of a hard-working nuclear family and a mysterious stranger whose skill with a gun saves them and makes way for the same civilization that turns the tables in Johnson's story. Old West makes way for the New West, all with the help of someone good with a gun.Though strong and probably forever deemed "classic," both films have their drawbacks. While John Wayne and James Stewart are their recognizable selves in "Liberty Valance," and Lee Marvin delivers yet another of his wonderful portrayals of villains doomed to die spectacularly, Wayne and Stewart at least are far too old for their parts. Each should be at least 20 years younger to faithfully play the young men who appear in Johnson's version. The woman torn between them, played by Vera Miles, who is otherwise fine, should also be correspondingly younger. One other quibble - the film was shot in large part at the studio, either on the backlot or on a sound stage. It's easy to miss the grand landscapes that usually accompany a John Ford film.The movie "Shane," meanwhile, has other problems. Alan Ladd plays an endearingly warm and friendly, not to say honorable, gunfighter. Jack Schaeffer's original conception of the character is significantly different. The Shane of the book is more potentially dangerous in his appearance - dressed in dark colors and a black hat. He's supposed to be able to put a chill through you. His impact on all three members of the family is far more complex and nuanced as a result - especially the attraction that builds between Shane and the wife, Marian. This is all treated in a more PG-rated fashion in George Stevens' film version. Another quibble - the story itself is dwarfed by the grandiose view of Wyoming's Tetons, where Stevens chose to shoot the exteriors. Novelist Schaeffer set his family's homestead on the prairie east of the Big Horns - where undistracted by the view, the drama played out among them takes on more stature. Finally, Brandon DeWilde's young Joey is less than perfect for the role - maybe too young, maybe misdirected, but lacking the presence and the depth that he has in the novel.But, any true western fan is going to overlook these shortcomings. Especially enjoyable is the crisp, black and white, widescreen print of "Liberty Valance," a film absolutely made for the big screen. And at 2 for one, this double bill is a great bargain.

reviewText: I'm not sure why these two particular westerns were paired in one double-disc set. They do both contain classic western stars, and include classic confrontations between heroes and black-hatted bad men. However, to me, "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" doesn't seem to be quite in the same class as "Shane" when it comes to acting and overall execution.John Wayne and James Stewart were both well into their careers when they starred in this 1962 movie about the folks of Shinbone and their dread of what psychopath Liberty Valance (played by Lee Marvin) would visit on them each time he rode into town with his crew. Both Wayne and Stewart seem to have settled into imitating their imitators for these performances. They both seem to be playing what would become Rich Little's caricatures of them, right down to Wayne's sashaying greeting of, "Howdy, Pilgrim."In spite of this, "Liberty Valance" has a redeeming conclusion and a host of implications that will leave you pondering for years to come. It poses the eternal question of who is better chosen to lead us -the man of action or the man of principle?The romance of the film centers on a woman's choice between these two necessary pillars of society. The movie makes us aware of our inevitable longing - always for the other. When we have action, we long for stability; when we have stability, we can never quite get the heroic vision of action out of our hearts.By contrast, "Shane" is perhaps the perfect western. My only disappointment with this disc was to find that "Shane" was actually made in color! Growing up, I'd just seen it on my black-and-white TV. I actually think it would have been better if it had been made in black-and-white. As it is, the colors of the background Grand Tetons where this film was set and shot detract from the mythic proportions of the players. Shane seems a little less impressive a figure riding into the lives of these plains settlers when we are distracted by the vivid palette of mountains behind him. Nevertheless, Shane ultimately stands up to both the mountains and the bad men.While the "Valance" disc doesn't contain any bonus features, "Shane" has a very worthwhile set of extras, including a commentary by George Stevens Jr. (who was on the set in 1953 with his father, the Producer), and Ivan Moffat, the film's Associate Producer. Moffat, the last surviving person who made an important contribution to the film, comes across as a crusty codger now willing to tell all. He gives some grumblingly juicy behind-the-scenes insights into the making of "Shane."For example, he reveals, a little ungallantly, that Jean Arthur was past fifty and looking like a gray-haired grandmother when she arrived on the set. However with the help of hair dye and make-up, she was readily enough transformed into the 30-something young mother that her character called for. Moffat also seems to have overcome some initial dislike of Alan Ladd in the lead. He mentions that while most of the actors in the film were conscientiously busy dirtying themselves up to look like authentic farmers, Alan Ladd could be found getting the complete star-treatment - lounging outside his trailer having manicures and his "false hair" fluffed. Nevertheless, Moffat concedes that, after all the other actors who'd been approached to fill the role, Ladd proved to be fortuitously the best possible choice.You might not find any compelling reason to get this 2-disc set unless you want to economically complete a collection of notable western films. Many viewers might find it enough to have "Shane," the ultimate romantic embodiment of the heroic loner who arrives to save the day - and then rides off as solitary and essentially mysterious as he came.
summary: If You're Holding Out for a Hero - You'll Find Several of Them Here

reviewText: This is a review for the double DVD set released by Paramount featuring THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE(1962) and SHANE (1953).THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE is in wide screen b&w;, directed by John Ford and stars John Wayne, James Stewart, Vera Miles and Lee Marvin along with a magnificent cast of character actors, some of them regulars in many of John Fords's previous directoral efforts.Critic/director Peter Bogdanovich has described THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE as the last classic film of Hollywood's  Golden Era and although I am not sure  when the golden era ended I wouldn't be able to muster much of an argument with him or anyone else who voiced appreciation for this incredible, dramatic, humorous and ultimately emotion filled movie.  Often this has been called a great western but I think it is so much morethan a genre picture.THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE is about how what we call civilization came to this country, different areas in different eras, and just as  importantly, how history is recorded and passed on down the generations.Ford shows us what the actual truth is and then explains to us that "When legend becomes fact, print the legend."  Just as he did in FORT APACHE Ford is telling us, among other things, that sometimes the unvarnished truth has to step aside for myths that will pass as facts in order to help encourage the advancement of civilization.Aside from all of the above, THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE is a cracking good story about a freshly minted lawyer who comes to the western town of Shinbone in a territorythat is yearning for statehood.  But the wealthy cattle ranchers are against US law coming to "both sides of the picket wire" and employ a gunman named Liberty Valance,played by Lee Marvin, to intimidate the new "sodbusters" and small businessmenwho are trying to build lives for themselves and their families.One thing leads to another and the young lawyer, Rance Stoddard played by Jimmy Stewart, with help from Tom Doniphin, played by John Wayne, eventually realizes that if he wantslaw & order in Shinbone and the surrounding area, he's going to have to use a gun toget it.That quick summary in no way relates how entertaining and exciting this classic film is.  And ultimately how heart wrenching it becomes. A movie that you'll never forget, when they refer to film  classics, this is one of the prototypes.SHANE (1953) was directed by George Stevens and stars Alan Ladd, Van Heflin, Jean Arthur (in her last screen appearance), Brandon De Wilde, Jack Palance and Ben Johnson, again, with a fine cast of character actors.  Shane is in really authentic looking  Technicolorand and was a full screen release.SHANE is played by Alan Ladd who drifts into a once open range which is now being homesteaded by "sodbusters," small farmers who are trying to make a go of it despite the harrassemt and occasional violence visited upon them by the big rancher in the area, the Ryker brothers,  who want to keep the range open for thier cattle to graze.Eventually,the Rykers hire a notorious gunman, played by Jack Palance, to help clear out the stubborn farmers once and for all.  The idea is first to threaten and then, if neccesary, to start killing the small farmers.  But the farmers rally behind Joe Starret.played by Van Heflin, and his hired man, Shane, to fight for the right to farm the open range.I think the thing I appreciate most about SHANE is the way both sides' positions are explained in a fairly even-handed way, although the Rykers are willing to do most anything to get what they want. SHANE was a trend setting film in its time and is still quite a good film to watch every now and then.  It has humor, excitement and and a little romance and is just a well done film, the kind everyone says can't be made anymoreOverall I give this double feature package of THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE and SHANEan enthusiastic five star rating, two fine films in one box for a relatively reasonable price.  Both films have the original trailers included as extras and SHANE has a very informative commentary track as well.  Both films have English subtitles and  Shanehas a French soundtrack included. I give this double feature set as high a recommendationas  possible.
summary: The Point Of A Gun Was The Only Law that Liberty Understood

reviewText: One of my most favorite gun fights is the climax of Shane. The guns sound real and I have always loved how the movie builds up to that intense situation. Also, Jack Palance moved like a hungry predator in the movie. What a cool bad-guy.Lee Marvin steals the show with his performance as Liberty Valance. The movie is old fashion fun, but the story about how media turns fiction into truth still wrings true today.These are classic Westerns that deserve to be seen by younger generations so that they can appreciate good story telling over special affects.
